subject: Re: [junit] RE: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts
msgSnippet: and the opposite: public void testReallyHard () { assertTrue(true); assertTrue(true); assertTrue(true); assertTrue(true); assertTrue(true); assertTrue(true);
messageBody:
and the opposite:

public void testReallyHard () {
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
assertTrue(true);
}

1 test and 10 assertions... great isn't it?

The point is: you can always give a false sense of security. Counting the # of asserts is not the holy graal.

I think that code coverage is a far better solution.

-Vladimir
